{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2993881,"name":"gartaud","username":"gartaud","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-18T16:11:48.440Z","cooked":"

Hello

Our team has been using CTRE motor controllers for a while and we were happy with them, but this year we have a hard time procuring them so we are considering switching to REV.

However, we cannot find a REV Software Reference Manual equivalent to the one from CTRE. It is our opinion that the “REV Software Resources” are very lacking. And the Migration manual from CTRE Phoenix to SPARK MAX is not as helpful as we had hoped it would be.

Does REV have a plan to release a proper Software Reference Manual at one point? Thanks.

A way to fully understand what features the REV motor controllers offer and how to use them without having to poke at the Javadoc and guessing what matters and what does not.

In other words, the equivalent of the pretty good “Phoenix Software Reference Manual”.

I wholeheartedly agree that Rev’s software documentation is very lacking in comparison to CTRE. CTRE makes it so easy with Phoenix Tuner. The documentation makes it very straightforward to use closed-loop control. With Rev, I am having trouble finding out what units it uses, namely for the feedforward term. With CTRE, I know that full output is considered 1023, but with Rev I don’t know for sure. Not sure how to calculate it either.

https://codedocs.revrobotics.com/java/com/revrobotics/sparkmaxpidcontroller#setReference(double,com.revrobotics.CANSparkMax.ControlType,int,double)

image1595×329 23.5 KB

image1267×359 23.3 KB

The docs explicitly state the FF units are in volts, or you can pass in an additional enum to specify percent out. It also explicitly states the units for position and velocity closed loop control.

There are docs explaining the Phoenix Tuner equivalent, the REV hardware client: Navigating the REV Hardware Client - SPARK MAX

And there are aptly named and well-commented code examples as well: SPARK MAX Code Examples - SPARK MAX

We have some issues with our school network blocking random CTRE documentation (and their new webpage leads to lots of 404s now).

So I’ve taken to mirroring everything:
Check out http://team2168.org/javadoc/

image703×206 5.73 KB

Includes:

  • javadocs for wpilib
  • javadocs for ctre and Rev libraries (with direct links to source code when the docs don’t answer your questions you can look at the implementation)
  • mirrors of the ctre and wpilib read-the-docs pages
  • links to common github example code

Mr.R_2:

I guess logically organized is subjective

Welcome to the curse of developing good documentation :).

IMO there’s two distinct modes of operation people have when searching for information:

  1. They don’t know what the don’t know
  2. They know what they don’t known.

In bucket 1 - you need a teacher-like pedagogy to ramp from zero-to-full, with plenty of side-tangents and diversions to ensure understanding both of the material at hand, and why it matters in context.

In bucket 2 - you just need a search bar that can convert a few keywords into the correct link.

CTRE put out their “bring-up” documents that help fulfill 1. I’ve started doing similar things for documentation at work, trying to do links in a “choose your own adventure” style to guide folks to the right chunk.

A key skill in good engineers I work with is the ability to self-realize when they’re in bucket 1, and do an appropriate level of pre-learning or investigation. But, other than being tossed in the deep end enough times to recognize when the bottom of the pool isn’t there… I’m not sure how to build this skill up.

Great analysis!

I think that REV has done an acceptable job with bucket #2, but I am looking for bucket #1 and coming back empty-handed…

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2022-01-18T17:55:44.393Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":207,"readers_count":206,"score":86.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":400627,"topic_slug":"rev-software-reference-manual","display_username":"gartaud","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/tag/1","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/tag/2","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24617,"username":"gerthworm","name":"Chris Gerth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31686,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Engineering Mentor, 1089 & 2495"},"post_url":"/t/rev-software-reference-manual/400627/11","custom_user_title":"Software Engineering Mentor, 1089 & 2495","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2993964,"name":"James","username":"otherguy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/otherguy/{size}/180121_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-18T18:05:20.074Z","cooked":"

I’d suggest looking at their code examples. (Linked in my above post and jtrvs above that)

You can get a lot done with position controller or speed controller

An exercise I’ll typically perform with the students is to just hook a motor controller/motor up to a wheel or gearbox.

Make code to spin to a specific rotational position.
Make code to drive it at a specific RPM.

Accomplishing those two things gives you a good point of reference for many mechanisms (usually just change gear ratios and conversion factors for units).

If you run into a problem/area that’s not covered by the examples, search GitHub for code other teams have posted, or ask here.

Thanks. I find the REV code examples a bit too simplistic.

It would be OK if we were off-season and had ample time to investigate, but that is sadly not the case.

That said, I have a couple of direct questions after looking at Migrating from CTRE Phoenix to SPARK MAX - SPARK MAX (revrobotics.com):

What is the IZone?

Why does one have to specify a parameter when calling getForward/ReverseLimitSwitch()? (what is the purpose of that parameter)

What is the equivalent API of CTRE getClosedLoopError()?

Thanks again.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2022-01-18T18:19:17.079Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":58.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":400627,"topic_slug":"rev-software-reference-manual","display_username":"gartaud","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.revrobotics.com/sparkmax/software-resources/migrating-ctre-to-rev","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Migrating from CTRE Phoenix to SPARK MAX - SPARK MAX","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":13843,"username":"otherguy","name":"James","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/otherguy/{size}/180121_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31686,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Engineering Mentor, 1089 & 2495"},"post_url":"/t/rev-software-reference-manual/400627/13","custom_user_title":"Software Engineering Mentor, 1089 & 2495","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2993990,"name":"James","username":"otherguy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/otherguy/{size}/180121_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-18T18:35:23.446Z","cooked":"
gartaud:

What is the IZone?

The area around zero error in which the integral term will be used as part of the closed loop controller (without this the i term accumulates error when you’re far away from your setpoint) this feature of the closed loop controller exists in CTRE’s api as well. usually set in a Gains configuration.

gartaud:

Why does one have to specify a parameter when calling getForward/ReverseLimitSwitch()?

Described in their docs. It accounts for whether or not you’re wired up to the normally open or normally closed connection on the limit switch.

team2168.org

CANSparkMax

declaration: package: com.revrobotics, class: CANSparkMax

gartaud:

What is the equivalent API of CTRE getClosedLoopError()?

not sure if there’s a built in method (I’m not an expert on their libraries).
You can always do subtraction though.

error = requested postion/velocity - actual position/velocity

actuals can be queried out of the motor through something like
cansparkmax.getEncoder().getVelocity()/getPosition()

gartaud:

What is the IZone?

To tack on - this one is more tied to knowing some background on common issues when working with PID controllers. See integrator anti-windup strategies: Integral windup - Wikipedia

gartaud:

What is the equivalent API of CTRE getClosedLoopError()?

This one I don’t know actually. The javadoc doesn’t seem to have anything that looks close: SparkMaxPIDController (FRC-REVLib API)

I was referring to the setFF() method of the SparkMax PID controller. According to the SparkMax docs, all I get is:

 /**
   * Set the Feed-froward Gain constant of the PIDF controller on the SPARK MAX. This uses the Set
   * Parameter API and should be used infrequently. The parameter does not presist unless
   * burnFlash() is called. The recommended method to configure this parameter is use to SPARK MAX
   * GUI to tune and save parameters.
   *
   * @param gain The feed-forward gain value
   * @return {@link REVLibError#kOk} if successful
   */

No units. Not to mention the misspelling of Feed-forward

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2022-01-18T20:09:18.661Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":172,"readers_count":171,"score":74.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":400627,"topic_slug":"rev-software-reference-manual","display_username":"Srinivas Deva","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":19731,"username":"jtrv","name":"Justin Tervay","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jtrv/{size}/203436_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49088,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/rev-software-reference-manual/400627/16","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2994108,"name":"Justin Tervay","username":"jtrv","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jtrv/{size}/203436_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-18T21:10:13.144Z","cooked":"

In this case, FF is based on the units of your setpoint.

https://docs.revrobotics.com/sparkmax/operating-modes/closed-loop-control

You will note that FF is multiplied by your setpoint and then added to the P, I, and D calculations. Arbitrary FF is added afterwards and is a separate feed forward, which is either percent out or volts.

I had thought you meant arbitrary FF earlier.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2022-01-18T21:10:13.144Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":168,"readers_count":167,"score":38.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":400627,"topic_slug":"rev-software-reference-manual","display_username":"Justin Tervay","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.revrobotics.com/sparkmax/operating-modes/closed-loop-control","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Closed Loop Control - SPARK MAX","clicks":10}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49088,"username":"srinivasdeva","name":"Srinivas Deva","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b9e5f3/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19731,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/rev-software-reference-manual/400627/17","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2994158,"name":"dyanoshak","username":"dyanoshak","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dyanoshak/{size}/65422_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-18T22:19:10.863Z","cooked":"

It is our goal to get closer to the bucket 1 methodology, teacher-like pedagogy, with all of our documentation for both FRC and FTC systems. We’re not there yet, but as others have suggested, please look at our examples and the code docs, and let us know what gaps you run in to. I’m going to ask some members of our software team to take a look at this thread and see where we can help.

srinivasdeva:

No units. Not to mention the misspelling of Feed-forward

As @jtrv pointed out, that constant is unitless because it is a gain value. We’ll get that spelling mistake fixed, good catch!

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2022-01-18T22:19:10.863Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":27,"reads":170,"readers_count":169,"score":209.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":400627,"topic_slug":"rev-software-reference-manual","display_username":"dyanoshak","primary_group_name":"REV","flair_name":"REV","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/d/b/db93216ec14c273ae2ca04aa396186c0461d0620.png","flair_bg_color":"F05A28","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":55,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/tag/1","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"REV Robotics","title_is_group":false,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9020,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/rev-software-reference-manual/400627/18","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2994252,"name":"gartaud","username":"gartaud","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-18T23:57:20.459Z","cooked":"

Thank you for your post. I am glad to read that you are aiming higher than the current situation regarding the documentation.

While probably not the most important, please find hereunder some suggestions on the CTRE-to-REV migration guide:

  1. Provide in appendix the list of all CTRE APIs and corresponding REV APIs. If a corresponding API is currently missing, add it even if the implementation is trivial (e.g. add equivalent of CTRE getClosedLoopError()). At the minimum, list very commonly used APIs such as CTRE setNeutralMode() / REV setIdleMode()

  2. Explain how to set the REV controllers to use the same native units as the CTRE controllers to allow brainless porting of CTRE-based code (assuming you have options like setPositionFactor() that can be applied wherever needed). Make it clear which APIs are impacted by changing those units. If not currently possible wherever needed, add APIs to do so.

  3. If the REV controllers offer options that are not commonly used with CTRE controllers, then suggest default values or approaches to find optimal values (e.g. IZone)

  4. Explain if conventions for “sensor phase” are the same between CTRE and REV. CTRE controllers are very peculiar on how to define forward and reverse directions for close-loop control, and require limit switches to be hardwired accordingly. If conventions are different, or can be redefined, explain.

Thanks!

Please find hereunder some comments on how to improve the Java code examples:

Alternate Encoder

  1. Add a comment above the line that calls getAlternateEncoder().
  2. Comment says “SparkMaxPIDController object is constructed by calling the getPIDController() method on an existing CANSparkMax object”. Is that true? I find it surprising that a getXXX method would construct an object rather than just return a reference to an existing object. That warrants more explanations.
  3. Specify ranges for kMaxOutput/kMinOutput. Are they normalized?

Analog Feedback Device

  1. Add comment above line that calls getAnalog()

Bus Measurements
N/A

Encoder Feedback Device

  1. The comment “The PID Controller can be configured to use the analog sensor as its feedback” seems a bad copy-and-paste from another example.

Get and Set Parameters
N/A

Limit Switch
I really don’t understand why one can pass kNormallyOpen or KNormallyClose to the APIs that return references to the limit switches. Shouldn’t that be an intrinsic property of the limit switches?

Motor Follower
N/A

Position Closed Loop Control
N/A

Read Encoder Values

  1. Could add a few lines to show how to set encoder positive direction if necessary and applicable

Smart Motion Example
Good stuff

Soft Limits

  1. Seems strange that the soft limits are enabled before they are set rather than the other way around.

Tank Drive With CAN
N/A

Velocity Closed Loop Control
See prior comments
